Award.AwardTitle: Was Subantarctic Dust a Major Driver of Past CO2 Variability?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
The scarcity of iron in seawater can limit the amount of carbon exported from surface to deep waters in areas of the global ocean where the concentration of major nutrients is high, yet phytoplankton growth is low. Of these, the Southern Ocean is the region where variations in iron availability have the largest effect on Earth?s carbon cycle through its fertilizing effect on marine ecosystems. The PIs propose to measure biological productivity and dust flux at five sites spanning the breadth of the Subantarctic Pacific, including one high-resolution site to reconstruct variability of these parameters across abrupt climate change events. These reconstructions will allow the PIs to test whether or not variations in dust flux and changes in biological productivity are correlated in the Subantarctic Pacific as they are in the Subantarctic Atlantic. If they are, results will support current estimates of the iron fertilization effect on lowering CO2. However, if they do not find evidence for iron fertilization in the South Pacific, then the estimated impact of iron fertilization on ice-age CO2 cycles must be reduced and other non- iron fertilization related processes would need to be invoked to account for lower glacial CO2 levels. The results of this study could transform understanding of the role of the Southern Ocean in regulating atmospheric CO2.

Broader impacts:
This project will foster a strong international collaboration and will train a postdoctoral researcher and two undergraduate students. This research will assess the past response to natural variability of iron input in the largest sector of the Southern Ocean.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Physical and biologic processes in the Southern Ocean affect the distribution of carbon dioxide (CO2) between the atmosphere and the ocean. Consequently, the Southern Ocean plays an important role in regulating the global climate system. Major climatic changes alter ocean circulation pathways and the amount of wind-blown dust delivered to the ocean surface, thus altering the supply of critical micronutrients (such as iron) to marine ecosystems. In turn, these variations in nutrient delivery and availability can enhance or diminish the efficiency of biologic pump to transfer carbon from the atmosphere to the deep ocean.

 

This project specifically examined variations in the efficiency of the biologic pump in the Pacific sector of the Southern Ocean, by far the largest region of the Southern Ocean, during past intervals of climatic change associated with global ice age cycles. Project scientists measured iron, organic carbon, and other chemical signatures in deep sea sediment cores to reconstruct changes in dust delivery, total iron supply, and biologic carbon export in the Pacific Southern Ocean over the past 300,000 years. These records span multiple episodes of continental ice sheet growth and retreat (on 100,000 year cycles) and were generated at sufficient resolution to additionally evaluate relatively short-term (1000-2000 year) variability in the efficiency of the biologic carbon pump.

 

Results indicate that wind-blown iron nutrient delivery to the Pacific Southern Ocean is higher during ice ages and short-term cold intervals, as observed in the Atlantic Southern Ocean and in ice core records from Antarctica. However, the biologic responses to these increases in nutrient supply appear to vary as a function of species and spatial location within the Pacific Southern Ocean. Project results suggest that increased wind-blown iron fertilizes marine ecosystems within the Pacific Southern Ocean during cold climate intervals, leading to increases in total nutrient utilization, biologic production and carbon export.
